subSubSection.paragraph:
R. persica , Lawson
in Hooker f. (1875: 638).

Typus
— INDIA . Garwhal,
Strachey
&
Winterbottom
7 ( K )
.

Description —Shrubs with many intricate spines, about 50 cm high, bright brownish yellow color, with intricate and twisted stems, pulvini and prostrate branches, spreading mostly on cliffs and rarely on rocks. Branches intricate, pubescent, brown to grey when young and glabrous, grey to brownish yellow when old. Leaves small, 3–10 × 2–5 mm , elliptic to ovoid, thin, greenish yellow, thick, simple, alternate, densely pubescent; base of leaves cuneate; apex of leaves obtuse; at the margin with many teeth, specially in upper 2/3 rarely entire; stipules filiform. Inflorescence in the axils of leaves. Flowers 1–2.5 mm long, small, yellow; calyx with four lobes; petals four, 1–2 mm long, linear; stamens longer than petals, anthers basifixed; disk very small; ovary with 2-3 locular and with 2–3 styls; peduncles 1.5–2.5 mm long. Fruits 2–2.5 mm long; glabrous with 2–3 seeds, with 2–3 furrows, mature fruits red. Seeds ovoid, 2 mm long.
Habitat and distribution — IRAN , AFGHANISTAN and PAKISTAN (specially in AFGHANISTAN ).

It grows in Irano-Turanian Region in C & E at an altitude of
1900–4000 m
, between 57° and 72° E and 30° and 33° N , on cliffs in Iran
.
It seems that, its main habitat is in Afghanistan
because of its widespread distribution in Afghanistan , meanwhile the leaves of this species in Iran , is about 2–3 time smaller than the leaves of this species in Afghanistan .
